title: Quiz 2: Labour Stages & Mechanisms
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Understanding the three stages of labour and mechanisms of fetal descent

questions.question: What characterizes the first stage of labour?
questions.explanation: The first stage of labour is characterized by cervical dilatation from 0 to 10 cm. It is the longest stage and includes the latent, active, and transition phases.
questions.hint: This stage involves opening of the cervix to allow the baby to pass through.

questions.question: The second stage of labour begins with complete cervical dilatation and ends with delivery of the fetus.
questions.explanation: True. The second stage begins when the cervix is fully dilated (10 cm) and ends with the delivery of the fetus. This is the pushing stage.
questions.hint: This is when the mother actively pushes to deliver the baby.

questions.question: What is the normal duration of the third stage of labour?
questions.explanation: The third stage of labour (placental delivery) typically lasts 5-30 minutes. If it exceeds 30 minutes, it is considered prolonged and may require intervention.
questions.hint: This stage involves delivery of the placenta and membranes.

questions.question: Which of the following are phases of the first stage of labour? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The first stage of labour has three phases: latent (0-3-4 cm), active (4-7 cm), and transition (8-10 cm). The expulsive phase is part of the second stage.
questions.hint: Think about the progression of cervical dilatation.

questions.question: Match each labour stage with its correct endpoint:
questions.explanation: First stage ends with complete cervical dilatation (10 cm), second stage ends with delivery of the fetus, and third stage ends with delivery of the placenta.
questions.hint: Consider what is delivered or completed at the end of each stage.

questions.question: Arrange the cardinal movements of labour in the correct order:
questions.explanation: The cardinal movements in order are: Engagement, Descent, Flexion, Internal rotation, Extension, External rotation, and Expulsion. These movements enable the fetus to navigate through the birth canal.
questions.hint: Start with the baby entering the pelvis and end with complete delivery.

questions.question: A multiparous woman is in the second stage of labour. How long would you expect this stage to last?
questions.explanation: In multiparas (women who have given birth before), the second stage typically lasts 15-30 minutes. Primigravidas usually have a longer second stage (1-2 hours).
questions.hint: Multiparas generally have shorter second stages than first-time mothers.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ phase of the first stage is characterized by rapid cervical dilatation from 4 cm to 7 cm.
questions.explanation: The active phase of the first stage is characterized by rapid cervical dilatation, typically from 4 cm to 7 cm. Contractions become stronger and more frequent during this phase.
questions.hint: This phase comes after the latent phase and before transition.

questions.question: What is the most reliable sign of placental separation during the third stage?

options.text: Gush of blood from the vagina

questions.explanation: The most reliable sign of placental separation is that the uterus becomes globular and firm as it contracts around the placenta. Other signs include lengthening of the cord and a gush of blood.
questions.hint: This sign involves the uterus changing shape as it contracts.

questions.question: The transition phase of the first stage is typically the most intense and shortest phase of labour.
questions.explanation: True. The transition phase (8-10 cm dilatation) is typically the most intense and shortest phase of the first stage. Women often experience strong contractions, nausea, and the urge to push during this phase.
questions.hint: This phase occurs just before complete cervical dilatation.
